Authors: Putri N.K.S., Rahman A., Qing C.H.G., Djojo B.W.
Title: Knowledge management systems in construction consulting company
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Putri, N.K.S., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Rahman, A., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Qing, C.H.G., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Djojo, B.W., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: As a construction consulting company, knowledge management is a crucial asset required to be competitively advantageous in the industry. It is not commonly practiced systematically, particularly in state owned companies. Hence, the purpose of this research is to develop a web-based knowledge management system design based on the path analysis results and TAM model to support state owned companies. The path analysis aims to determine the extent of the employee's intention to support knowledge management system creation. The data will be collected from 63 respondent questionnaire, interviews and observation in the construction consulting company. The research results revealed the significance between attitude toward computer and organizational culture toward the intentions of employees using knowledge management systems. Therefore, the knowledge management system design is recommended to apply in the company with the suggestive KMS features. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Knowledge management system; OOAD; Path analysis; State owned companies; TAM
Index Keywords: Behavioral research; Human resource management; Knowledge based systems; Regression analysis; Surveys; Systems analysis; Consulting companies; Knowledge management system; Organizational cultures; Path analysis; Research results; State-owned companies; Support knowledge; Web based; Knowledge management

Authors: Ongowarsito H., Djojo B.W., Ferino F.
Title: The Impact of e-CRM Implementation to Bank Performance Through e-Service Quality
Source title: Proceedings of 2018 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2018
Affiliations: Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, School of Information Systems, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ongowarsito, H., Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, School of Information Systems, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Djojo, B.W., Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Ferino, F., Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this research was to analyze the impact of e-CRM implementation on bank performance through e-Service Quality and what are the features to be concerned further. The study was conducted in the business process of public bank in Jakarta. The questionnaires were distributed to 58 corporate customers of this public bank using cluster sampling method. Analysis obtained using quantitative research with partial least square (PLS) model. The result of this study found that e-CRM system helps bank performance to accelerate the registration process, product implementation, and help customer dealing with various feature offered. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: bank performance; e-CRM implementation; e-Service Quality
Index Keywords: Information management; Surveys; Bank performance; Business Process; Cluster sampling; Corporate customers; E-service quality; Partial least square (PLS); Quantitative research; Registration process; Quality of service

Authors: Sudrajat D., Djojo B.W., Adhikara C.T., Kartikasari D.
Title: The effect of ownership of logistics physical asset and integrated ICT to innovative capability and its impact on firm performance
Source title: Proceedings of 2017 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2017
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sudrajat, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Djojo, B.W., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Adhikara, C.T., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kartikasari, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Innovation constitutes the most importance aspect to improve firm performance. Resources were indispensable by the companies to support firm's innovative capabilities. Nevertheless, whether or not all resources had significant impact on innovative capability and firm performance. The research intended to examine the effect of ownership of logistics physical assets (tangible resource) and integrated ICT (intangible resource) on innovative capability and firm performance. This research was a causal research, organization as unit of analysis, manager or director as unit of observation, probability sampling as sampling method, and sampling size consisted of 280 logistics service companies in Jakarta (Jabodetabek) Region. This research examined the effect of ownership of logistics physical asset on innovative capability, the effect of ownership of integrated ICT on innovative capability, the effect of innovative capability on firm performance, the effect of ownership of logistics physical asset directly on firm performance or indirectly pass through innovative capability, and the effect of ownership of integrated ICT directly on firm performance or indirectly pass through innovative capability. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: firm performance; innovative capability; integrated ICT; Logistics physical assets
Index Keywords: Firm Performance; Innovative capability; Intangible resources; integrated ICT; Logistics services; Physical assets; Probability sampling; Tangible resources; Information management

Title: How e-Commerce web quality and customer experiences can take the online purchase intention up? Case study: E-commerce of general insurance product
Source title: Journal of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Affiliations: Kusuma Negara Business School/STIE Kusuma Negara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Bins Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Arief, Kusuma Negara Business School/STIE Kusuma Negara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Djojo, B.W., Bins Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Purnomo, H., Kusuma Negara Business School/STIE Kusuma Negara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Companies need innovation to keep the existence and business sustainability in long term. One of the innovation way was using technology as well as e-Commerce to achieve the company goals. But, how e-Commerce can make customers to take an online purchase intention up to company goals? The purpose of this research is to find out the relationship of e-Commerce web quality and customer experiences to online purchase intention of general insurance agent e-Commerce web. It might create customer interest to buy insurance online through e-Commerce quality and customer experiences. The research used primary data by spreading the questionnaires to 100 respondents who lived in Jakarta. The analysis method used Component Based Structural Equation Modeling (CB-SEM) or Partial Least Square (PLS) by WarpPLS Software Version 3.0. The results obtained e-Commerce to take up a purchase insurance online, easily accessible, including claims service so the agent can expand the business by eliminating geographical restrictions. © Medwell Journals, 2017.
Author Keywords: Customer experiences; Customers; E-Commerce quality; General; Insurance; Online purchase intention

Authors: Djojo B.W., Arief M., Heriyati P., Krisnamurthi B.
Title: Purchase intention of microinsurance: By client value or trust?
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kusuma Negara Business School-STIE Kusuma Negara, Jakarta, 13770, Indonesia; School-Management, Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Agricultural Economics, Institute Pertanian Bogor, Bogor, 16680, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Djojo, B.W., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Arief, M., Kusuma Negara Business School-STIE Kusuma Negara, Jakarta, 13770, Indonesia; Heriyati, P., School-Management, Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Krisnamurthi, B., Agricultural Economics, Institute Pertanian Bogor, Bogor, 16680, Indonesia
Abstract: This research is a pre-test research that has a purpose to find out the purchase intention of microinsurance would be triggered by client value or trust and which one would significantly contribute on this relationship. The pre-test research used primary data by spreading the questionnaires to 177 respondents who lived in Jakarta. The analysis method was Component Based Structural Equation Modeling (CB-SEM) or Partial Least Square (PLS) by using WarpPLS software version 3.0. The results were Trust has a significant relationship to Purchase Intention, Client Value has insignificant relationship to Purchase Intention, but if there was Trust, it will increase the Purchase Intention. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Customer value; Microinsurance; Purchase intention; Trust

Title: Exploring the factors affecting consumer purchase intention towards children multivitamin products based on purchase store
Affiliations: School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Djojo, B.W., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Arief, M., Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to explore the factors affecting consumer purchase intention towards children multivitamin products based on purchase store at Jakarta and its surrounding cities, such as Bogor, Depok, Tangerang and Bekasi. This study was conducted in a quantitative research with descriptive purpose. The primary data was collected from 250 respondents and divided into two groups, 180 respondents of experienced consumers group and 70 respondents of potential consumers groups. The study findings indicated that ‘purchase store was closed to home or office,’ ‘cheaper price or discount,’ and ‘usually become a habit’ were the important consideration factors to make consumer purchase intention. The other findings showed that supermarket, drug store and pharmacy were the three favorite stores to purchase children multivitamin products. For practical implication, the result of this study showed a clear picture and information about the factors those could determine consumer behavior in purchase intention based on purchase store further, especially for marketers. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Children multivitamin products; Purchase intention; Purchase store

Authors: Djojo B.W., Arief M., Heriyati P.
Title: Exploring the relationship of distribution channel role to trust and purchase intention of microinsurance
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Djojo, B.W., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Arief, M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Heriyati, P., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to explore the relationship of distribution channel role to trust and purchase intention of microinsurance at Jakarta and its surrounding cities, such as Bogor, Depok, Tangerang and Bekasi. This study was conducted in a quantitative research with descriptive-causal purpose. The primary data was collected from 35 respondents as a pre-test research. This pre-test study findings indicated that distribution channel role had a significant relationship to trust and had no significant relationship to make consumer purchase intention. The other findings showed that simple information, assurance service, offer the accessibility and understandable information were the strong points of distribution channel role. The others indicators were trustworthiness, consistency, integrity of product and responsiveness were the strong indicators of trust. For practical implication, customer would intent to purchase the microinsurance product because of price, trust to insurer and product. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Distribution channel role; Microinsurance; Purchase intention; Trust
